TextView.android:text: By Jocelyn Thao and Danielle Wong

When stressed or anxious, many of us tend to tense up and sometimes forget to breathe properly. Breathing exercises are a universally-effective way to relieve such feelings since they instantly your slow heart rate, making you feel instantly calmer. Slow Breathing or Deep Breathing? Despite popular belief, slow breathing is much easier and more efficient than deep breathing. It’s one of the best techniques for easing a panic attack because it calms your body systems and slows your heart rate. While you are slowly breathing, scan your body for anywhere you are holding tension, such as your jaw, lips, and shoulders. Allow the tension to flow out and relaxation to flow in. Simple Breathing Exercise: This breathing technique is an easy and effective method for relieving anxiety; all you need to do is breathe out slowly. It is important to focus on your exhales and try to ignore your inhales. This will cause your inhales to naturally lengthen as your exhales do. When the pace of your breaths is slower, you can focus on the rest of your body and try to relieve tension elsewhere, such as in your lips, jaw, or shoulders. As you continue to slowly exhale, you will feel relief from the tension you’ve been holding, and you’ll start to feel more relaxed. Find the right exercise for you. Guided relaxation, meditation, and yoga are the three most popular methods to relieve stress through breathing. Do yoga and meditation when you feel a sense of constant anxiety because they increase your awareness of how you are breathing. A simple guided meditation around 10 minutes is a perfect way to alleviate stress if you are on a time crunch. If breathing exercises aren’t your thing, physical activity promotes the same benefits as the other exercises listed above. How can you tell if breathing exercises are working? A smartphone app to track your heart rate is a great way to see your progress and results. These apps are simple: place your finger over your camera and have the app’s camera measure your pulse. Using an app is a convenient way to access and visualize your results.
